So Moses brought Israel from the Red Sea, and they went out into the wilderness of Shur, and they went three days in the wilderness and no water. Now let me ask you, does God know that you need water? Absolutely. He made us. He created us. He knows that we need water. And the Bible tells us, and they went, and they came, notice in verse 23, and when they came to Marah, they could not drink the waters of Marah. Why? For they were bitter, therefore the name of it was called Marah. And the people, they got together and they said, let's see what God's going to do. Let's see how God's going to work. Do you remember what He did in Egypt? Do you remember what He did at the Red Sea? Do you remember how He parted at the Red Sea? No, they didn't say any of that. They murmured, the Bible says, against Moses saying, what shall we drink? He cried unto the Lord. The Lord showed him a tree and he cast it. But the Bible says at the end of verse number 25, notice what the Bible says. I'll read the entirety of it. And he cried unto the Lord and the Lord showed him a tree, which when he had cast in the waters, the waters were made sweet. There he made for them a statute and ordinance and there he proved them. God proves us. You're going to trust Him? You see God work. They were eyewitnesses of His great work. They got to see God do something that no one had ever seen before. This group of people in Exodus chapter number 14, they experienced something that no other group of people have ever experienced. The Jordan River is a different situation. You can read it in the book of Joshua. But this circumstance here in Exodus chapter number 14, only this group of people experienced this personally. And though they experienced some great, mighty work of God, they come to the next trial and they murmur. They forget what God is able to do. I hope that it would not be the case for you or for me. I hope that as God allows us to be eyewitnesses of His great power, as God would allow us to see His great work in our lives, that when we face those next times of difficulty, when we have that next trial and that next test, that we would have great excitement and enthusiasm about what is God going to do? How is God going to work? Because we get to see what God is able to do. Listen, it's exciting to see God work. It really is. But many times, you know what has to happen before you see God work? A dilemma, a problem, a difficulty. You know how most of us deal with difficulties? We don't like them. We try to avoid them at all costs, right? But we see that God leads us. And at times, as God is leading us, He is leading us directly into a place where He's going to prove His great power. He's going to show you His work. Turn to the book of Psalms, if you will. We'll finish with this in Psalm 119. In Psalm 119, there's a verse of Scripture here that I want to close our service with this morning. I hope that it would be a verse that would be a prayer of each of ours this morning and this week. In Psalm 119, in verse number 126, the Bible says this, it is time for thee, Lord, to work. For they have made void thy law. No doubt, we live in the midst of a place where they've made void the law of God. We understand that. But I want you to see that statement to begin the verse, it is time for Thee, Lord, to work. I wonder this morning, how many of us are anxious to see God work? I mean desiring to see God do something, that we would surrender and yield our lives to God and say, God, I just want to see you work. I want to see you. Listen, it's all for God's glory. It's not for my glory. It's not for your glory. It's all for His glory. And we would be careful, even as they sang the praise, to understand that the Lord, it is He that hath worked gloriously, triumphed gloriously. And we find this morning that we would pray and say, God, it's time, Lord, for Thee to work. We long to see you work in our lives personally, in our church, corporately, in our nation. We long, God, to see you work. God is able. The children of Israel faced a great difficulty, but God wasn't concerned for one moment. For God knew that He led them exactly to that place, and He was going to show His great power. And they were eyewitnesses of His great work. This morning, I enjoy reading about, I enjoy listening to people give testimony about what God has done. But the most exciting is seeing God work personally. And I want to be an eyewitness of God's great work in my life, in your life, in our lives corporately. Let's see what God will do as we yield and surrender to Him, that we would give God the glory for He is worthy of it. Let's pray together. Father, we love You. How we thank You for loving us. We thank You this morning for this record that's given to us in Exodus 14. Many of us this morning are familiar with this portion of Scripture. No doubt within a group this size, there are some that would say, that's my favorite account of all of God's Word. I love that passage of Scripture. God, I pray this morning, as we've had the opportunity to go through and to learn from this portion of Scripture, God, You would help us to have that longing of the psalmist. It is time for Thee, Lord, to work, that we would be eyewitnesses, just as the children of Israel here in Exodus 14, that we be eyewitnesses of Your great work. I pray, God, that this morning You would help Your people. No doubt there's some that are dealing with some difficulties, some dilemmas, some situations that from a human perspective seem to be no way out, no path forward. I'm so thankful that in those circumstances, in those situations, You love to prove Your power. I pray, God, that You would work and move in hearts and lives as only You can. There's someone this morning that's not sure of heaven. I pray that today, Lord, they'd understand their need for Christ. Give us an opportunity to take a Bible and show them how they could know for sure that heaven is their home. We pray that in these few moments of invitation that You'd have Your will and way. We'll thank You for each decision that will be made, for it's in Christ's name we pray. Would You stand with me? Heads are bowed, eyes are closed. He's going to play quietly on the piano this morning.
